image.altText: A smiling man hugs a woman, surrounded by people and cameras

props.synopsis: In the two years since Labor made the key election promise that helped it win government in SA, ramping has become significantly worse — but failing to fix the crisis may not necessarily cost the government the next election.

title.children: Will voters care if SA Labor breaks its promise to fix the 'ramping crisis'?

image.altText: Callum and Jake smiling and holding a dog.

props.synopsis: Mexican authorities say they believe two Australian tourists and their American friend were shot dead by thieves who were trying to steal their car for its tyres.

title.children: Australian brothers may have been killed because thieves wanted their car tyres, Mexican authorities say

image.altText: A CFS truck and personnel stand outside a historic mine shaft and engine house

props.synopsis: Police say the man became stuck trying to rescue his puppy, which slid 5 to 8 metres down a mine shaft in South Australia.

title.children: Man and puppy rescued from heritage mine shaft

image.altText: A composite image of three men, all looking at the camera.

props.synopsis: Russia's policy of encouraging convicts to bolster its invasion of Ukraine was simple — survive six months and get your freedom. Some returned to the communities they once terrorised, only to commit new crimes.

title.children: Putin told killers and cannibals to 'atone for their crime on the battlefield'. It didn't end well

image.altText: Antony Loewenstein sits at his desk by his computer and looks at the camera

props.synopsis: Antony Loewenstein's investigations on Israel have earned him acclaim around the world, but within his own community, he has been labelled a traitor.

title.children: Jewish journalist Antony Loewenstein on why he feels compelled to speak out against Gaza war

image.altText: Dirty money image

props.synopsis: Buying a home? Soon you won't have as much competition from drug dealers, corrupt officials and criminals with dirty money thanks to new laws and a boost to enforcement.

title.children: New laws to stem drug dealers, corrupt officials and dirty money from heating up our real estate market

image.altText: A man with a serious expression stands in front of a boat on the water

props.synopsis: Pressure to secure reliable drinking water for South Australia's Eyre Peninsula is mounting as the region's main water source is quickly depleting. But a prominent aquaculture business says the only solution puts its multimillion dollar company at risk.

title.children: This mussel grower says his business is at risk, and it's all related to his town's dire need for drinking water

image.altText: A side-by-side image shows David McBride in pale blue linen shirt and Richard Boyle in suit and patterned tie

props.synopsis: Governments like to be seen to be supporters of whistleblowers, but when it comes to the crunch, perception and reality are two different things and tough talk often becomes hostage to excruciating long delays or watered-down reforms, writes Adele Ferguson.

title.children: Real Australians understand the value of whistleblowers, but when it comes to the crunch, our leaders are slow on reform

image.altText: An image of a scoreboard.

props.synopsis: The Fitzroy Community Club thrashed the Elizabeth Football Club at the round four game in Adelaide's north on Saturday, scoring 82 goals and 24 behinds.

title.children: Local football team scores remarkable 516-0 win in Adelaide Footy League game

image.altText: Emergency service vehicles in an empty car park.

props.synopsis: Saturday's stabbing in Willetton had all the hallmarks of a terrorist attack, according to police, but they stopped short of giving it that label. But questions are being asked about whether Australia is doing enough to counter online radicalisation.

title.children: The Perth teenager shot dead by police was taking part in a deradicalisation program. Experts say Australia's youth are particularly vulnerable

image.altText: A blond-haired older man in impressive medieval armour rides a white horse through between soldiers with spears.

props.synopsis: The British actor is best known for playing a ship's captain in Titanic and a king in the Lord of the Rings films that won a combined 22 Oscars.

title.children: Bernard Hill, known for roles in The Lord of the Rings and Titanic, dies aged 79

image.altText: Jim Chalmers pulls a face at a press conference.

props.synopsis: Next week's federal budget will once again collect more in tax than expected, raking in an extra $25 billion over the five-year budget forecasting period.

title.children: Federal budget to haul in extra cash once again, but less than in previous years

image.altText: A nurse prepares for surgery wearing blue scrubs and a surgical mask and pulling on a pair of gloves in an operating theatre.

props.synopsis: Thousands of patients caught COVID in Victorian public hospitals in the past two years and hundreds died, fuelling concerns that health services aren't taking strong enough precautions against airborne viruses.

title.children: Thousands of patients caught COVID in Victorian hospitals in the last two years and almost one in 10 died, new data shows

image.altText: Blonde woman holds eye iPad to her face. The iPad screen shows the covered side of her face as a glam photograph

props.synopsis: Chelsea Bonner has been fighting to change unrealistic perceptions of beauty for decades. Now she's taking on her biggest foe yet – artificial intelligence.

title.children: Fighting the AI fakes: How your images are being manipulated, and the woman trying to stop it

image.altText: Anthony Albanese grimaces while looking across the table at Peter Dutton as he speaks

props.synopsis: In its messy handling of the case surrounding a violent assault on a Perth grandmother last week, the government has revealed a vulnerability that — without a reset  — could snowball into a lasting and enduring problem, writes Patricia Karvelas.

title.children: No-one gets a political leave pass because they didn't create the problem. Labor's messy week reveals deeper vulnerabilities

image.altText: A woman in a white shirt and a man in a short-sleeve blue button-down shirt stand in a kitchen together.

props.synopsis: In the midst of national domestic violence and housing crises, one service is looking to landlords to help solve both.

title.children: Could landlords help people fleeing family domestic violence? This service thinks so

image.altText: A white woman in an electric wheelchair is walking her dog with a pink leash. She's in front of green grass and a BRISBANE sign

props.synopsis: While those fleeing a violent partner are eligible for a $5,000 payment, that doesn't apply to those trying to escape a carer or family member.

title.children: Women with disabilities fear government response to domestic violence threat will leave them behind

image.altText: A white woman with long blonde hair stands in an office holding two babies in pink onesies.

props.synopsis: Labor will spend $50 million to fund 1,850 places in the Primary Care Nursing and Midwifery Scholarship Program over four years.

title.children: Will a new scholarship fund for nurses be enough to bridge major gaps in women's health?

image.altText: A teacher and nursing student in a prac hospital room.

props.synopsis: The government announces a new $319 weekly practical payment to ease the financial strain of unpaid student placements.

title.children: Government unveils funding lifeline for cash-strapped uni students doing mandatory unpaid placements

image.altText: Silhoutte of a woman sitting on a sofa in a dark room

props.synopsis: Women who have left a violent relationship could be given wrist-worn duress alarms and home security upgrades to help them stay in their communities, under a four-year, $230 million NSW government package to combat domestic violence.

title.children: Secret duress alarms, security upgrades part of NSW government's emergency domestic violence package

image.altText: A view looking towards suburban housing from a golf course fairway.

props.synopsis: Adrienne and Glenn Pearson joined about 700 neighbours for a court showdown against a housing development on an abandoned golf course, but now the Queensland government has stepped in.

title.children: This empty golf course could be 'called in' to increase housing supply. Experts say it might be wishful thinking

image.altText: Close up shot of arms holding a small child, whose bare leg and foot are visible.

props.synopsis: Queensland public servants will soon receive 10 days of paid leave to access reproductive healthcare including IVF and fertility treatments, care for endometriosis, and preventative screenings for breast and prostate cancer.

title.children: Treatment for IVF, fertility, endometriosis to be covered under new paid leave scheme for public servants

image.altText: Three candidates smile for the cameras

props.synopsis: After decades of attempts, the Greens look all but certain to claim a history-making seat in Tasmania's upper house.

title.children: Early election results sees Greens looking to claim first Tasmanian upper house seat

image.altText: An older man with white hair looks serious as he stands in front of a blue and white Israeli flag.

props.synopsis: The decision is an escalation of Israel's long-running feud with Al Jazeera, which it accuses of bias, and also threatens to heighten tensions with Qatar, which owns the channel.

title.children: Israel orders Al Jazeera to close its offices in Israel, as Netanyahu labels it an 'incitement channel'

image.altText: A composite image of a man drawing a wombat on a wall, and a drawing three women soccer players.

props.synopsis: When Jimmi Buscombe created Gutsy the wombat under a Warrnambool bridge six years ago, he could never have imagined where it would lead him.

title.children: From marsupials to Matildas, how a viral wombat mural changed an ex-chef's life

image.altText: Composite image of Kim Kardashian, Doja Cat, Lady Gaga and Rihanna at the Met Gala

props.synopsis: The fundraiser is arguably one of the biggest fashion events of the year, with designers showing off some of their boldest designs using the biggest pop culture figures as models.

title.children: The Met Gala is tomorrow. Here are some of the iconic looks from past years

image.altText: Young girl with long brunette hair smiles, wearing sky blue blazer

props.synopsis: A Queensland paramedic has established her own training project hoping to boost trauma-informed practice among first responders.

title.children: 'All the evidence is on you': Why trauma-informed care by first responders is so critical for sexual assault victim-survivors

image.altText: A camera sits high above a window on a business

props.synopsis: CCTV has captured the horror that unfolded when a knife-wielding teen was shot dead by WA police in a Bunnings car park.

title.children: This camera captured the horror that unfolded when a knife-wielding teen was shot dead by police

image.altText: Police block roads on a deserted street at night

props.synopsis: Police have shot dead a 16-year-old boy who stabbed a member of the public, saying the teenager was "radicalised" online.

title.children: Police shoot dead 'radicalised' 16yo armed with a knife in WA

image.altText: A composite photo of three NRL players holding rugby balls

props.synopsis: The Brisbane Broncos are dealing with a big injury issue, while South Sydney and the Warriors just have issues after falling to more defeats. Here's this week's NRL Round-Up.

title.children: NRL Round-Up: Souths continue to struggle, the Broncos injuries mount and Reed Mahoney's protection services

image.altText: AFLR8

props.synopsis: A few unheralded young guns are starting to come to the AFL party, while established stars are shining. Here's this week's wrap.

title.children: AFL Round-Up: Freo finds a trump card, Saints have a gem, and Petty proves his worth

image.altText: cattle in a holding pen

props.synopsis: Four years on from the pandemic beginning, has the beef industry found its feet in a changed market or do lingering COVID scars remain?

title.children: Is the 'resilient' Australian beef industry primed to thrive after COVID?

image.altText: An older middle-aged man in a blue bulletproof vests walks in the desert near a bright yellow ambulance and two soldiers.

props.synopsis: Israel's military says a barrage of rockets fired from the besieged Gaza Strip towards Kerem Shalom kills three soldiers and wounds a dozen others, causing it to shut down the border crossing used to deliver humanitarian aid into Gaza.

title.children: Three Israeli soldiers killed as Hamas attacks Gaza border crossing, prompting Israel to halt aid deliveries

image.altText: Man holds large oyster alongside his trophy

props.synopsis: After 55 years growing oysters, Bernie Connell and his oyster 'Jill' look set to break world records after this weekend's Narooma Oyster Festival on the NSW far south coast.

title.children: Oyster weighing more than 3kg wins Australian title, grower waits on world record confirmation
